revisions.*:
'''Fenton Robinson''' (September 23, 1935 — November 25, 1997<ref name="Dead"/>) was an [[United States|American]] [[blues]] singer and exponent of the [[Chicago blues]] guitar.

==Biography==
Born in [[Greenwood, Mississippi]], [[United States]], Robinson left his home at the age of 18 to move to [[Memphis, Tennessee]] where he recorded his first single "Tennessee Woman" in 1957.<ref name="russell">{{cite book
| first= Tony
| last= Russell
| year= 1997
| title= The Blues - From [[Robert Johnson (musician)|Robert Johnson]] to [[Robert Cray]]
| edition= 
| publisher=Carlton Books Limited 
| location= Dubai
| pages= 159–160
| isbn= 1-85868-255-X}}</ref> He settled in [[Chicago]] in 1962.<ref name="russell"/> He recorded his [[signature song]], "Somebody Loan Me a Dime", in 1967 on the Palos label, the nationwide distribution of which was aborted by a freak snow storm hitting the Windy City.  Covered by [[Boz Scaggs]] in 1969, the song was misattributed, resulting in legal battles.  It has since become a blues standard, being "part of the repertoire of one out of every two blues artists", according to 1997's ''Encyclopedia of Blues''.<ref>{{cite book | last = Herzhaft | first = Gérard |author2=Harris Herzhaft |author3=Paul Harris |author4=Brigitte Debord |author5=Jerry Haussler |author6=Anton J. Mikofsky  | others = Brigitte Debord  (trans.)| title = Encyclopedia of the Blues | publisher = University of Arkansas Press | year = 1997 | isbn = 1-55728-452-0 | url = http://books.google.com/books?id=sOKZKESWys0C&pg=PA278&dq=%22Somebody+Loan+Me+a+Dime%22+Robinson&client=firefox-a | page = 278}}</ref> 

Robinson re-recorded the song for the critically acclaimed album ''[[Somebody Loan Me a Dime]]'' in 1974, the first of three he would produce under the [[Alligator Records]] label.<ref name=blues>{{cite book | last = Tomko | first = Gene | chapter = Robinson, Fenton | chapterurl = http://books.google.com/books?id=sOKZKESWys0C&pg=PA278&dq=%22Somebody+Loan+Me+a+Dime%22+Robinson&client=firefox-a | title = Encyclopedia of the Blues: A - J | editor = Edward M. Komara | publisher = Routledge | year = 2006 | isbn = 0-415-92699-8 | page = 835}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | last = Cochran | first = Robert | title = Our Own Sweet Sounds: A Celebration of Popular Music in Arkansas | publisher = University of Arkansas Press | year = 2005 | isbn = 1-55728-793-7 | url = http://books.google.com/books?id=TRFe-4vC76AC&pg=PA58&dq=%22Somebody+Loan+Me+a+Dime%22+Robinson&lr=&client=firefox-a | page = 58}}</ref> Robinson was nominated for a [[Grammy Award]] for the second, 1977's ''I Hear Some Blues Downstairs''.<ref name=blues/>

In the 1970s he was arrested and imprisoned for involuntary manslaughter in connection with a car accident. Paroled after nine months, he continued playing in Chicago clubs and later taught guitar.

Robinson died of complications from [[Brain tumor|brain cancer]],<ref name="Dead">[http://thedeadrockstarsclub.com/1996.html Thedeadrockstarsclub.com - accessed November 2009]</ref> in [[Rockford, Illinois]].
